Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:In the movie a fragile man is causing accidents, his hope is to find a person opposite of him who is what? Choices:  A: undestroyable B: unbreakable C: indestructible D: durable E: invisible<n><n>### Response:		<n>The actor character in that movie was looking for an "indestructible" partner to balance him out. He hoped that finding such an individual would help "balance" him out.<n>### Rationales: <n>This choice is the most apt description for the answer because "indestructible", meaning unbreakable, durable, and invincible, is the definition for the word "opposite" in the statement. <n>It also mentions that "indestructible is the definition for "opposite," so it means that the desired person has this characteristic. <n><n>Option D: Durable is incorrect because, in the context of the sentence, it does not mean "opposite; but rather, it only implies the presence of a partner who is unbreakable, undestroyable, or immortal which, when contrasted with the man on screen, is not enough to indicate that he desires an opposing and balancing influence. <n><n>Option C: Invincible is incorrect since it does not imply that the character intended for this person to be the opposite of himself and that the character desired a person who would be perfect without flaws but with some defect that would balance out the character.<n><n>Option C: Invisible means that the character desired "to find a person opposite of himself who was undeposable, but this interpretation is incorrect since the character was looking for an oppose, not an undeposable character.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: It looks like there are several choices here, but some are phrased differently. "complex" is singular for the most part, so we can eliminate Choice A and Choice E. The other choices contain "complex" as plural. "movie" is a specific type of movie, so it can be ruled out. Choice C is too specific — "space center" — which would seem to suggest that the launch pad isn't part of the launch complex because we can eliminate "space center". Likewise, "military installation" can be quickly eliminated because the launch pad is not a military installation. Therefore, "cape kennedy" and "spaceship centre" are the proper answer, but because they sound similar and are quite close together, it might be best not to have a comma between them. Answer: Cape Kennedy/Spaceship Centre<n><n>### Input:"So, the students were excited to finish the work and share it." True or False?<n><n>### Response:"So, the students _were_ excited to finish [this work and] to share [it]." or "So, the students _do_ exciting to finish [this work] and to share [it]".<n><n>### Input:#. The teacher asked the homework question on a whiteboard, so students could see it for themselves. Did that help?<n><n>### Output:#. Yes. It showed how far they'd already come.<n><n>### Input/Output Example<n>- Input: Students who take notes or speak out loud while reading a book often remember more of it because what?<n>- Response: They understand the context.<n><n>### Further Examples/Tasks with Feedback<n>- Tutorials for Further Examples: **[here](docs/tutorials.md)**<n><n>### Suggested Reading<n>- [Leadership](http://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/the-secrets-of-the-best-teachers?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+hbswk+%28HBRWomen%29) by Paul Reville<n>- [The Science of Learning](http://www.scienceoflearning.org/sites/default/files/PDFs/SOLE_Final_Report
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: In this statement, the main content is: "He wore the wrong sho…." It's important to consider the content of the statement first and foremost to ensure that your answer is as clear and concise as possible. Choice A, "exercise", may seem obvious, it is, but there is no reason to include it as an answer when "exercise" is an implicit aspect for everything, including walking. Also, the statement never said that he exercised all day. Choices B, "moving forward", and D, "blisters" are both irrelevant as the content is "he wore the wrong shoes" and not "the he wore [wore] the wrong shoes." Choice C, can be left out as it's repetitive with Choice B.<n><n>Choice E, "locomotion," is unnecessary. It's implied in the statement and thus doesn't need to be explicitly elaborated on. It's essentially repeating the content of the entire statement and thus, doesn't add any additional value. <n><n>There is only one answer that is correct and thus answer is C, "feet."<n>Answer: C: feet
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:When he was a small child he called the giraffe mascot a cow, it was a fond memory of the now defunct what? Choices:  A: toy store B: story book C: great outdoors D: countryside E: wildlife refuge<n><n>### Response:		His story has a sad ending when he tried to find a toy store and couldn't find it.<n><n>### Input:`These are very important books, they're a must-read especially for women who want to pursue their dreams while staying home.` It is a sentence that describes...Choices:  A: an argument B: a review C: a recommendation D: a reflection E: a parody<n><n>### Response:`It is a sentence that describes a recommendation!`<n><n>### Example of wrong input<n><n>`The task:  Design an algorithm that searches for "Jones" within a string<n><n>Input:  Given the empty string, will the algorithm return a boolean output? Will it return a single Jones, multiple Jones, Joneses, or no Jones?<n><n>Output:  Will it be true? Will it be an empty set? Will it contain the string? Will it not contain anything?<n><n>Choice A: Design an algorithm.`<n><n>### Example response 1:This would be a good choice because it tells you what you're supposed to do with no hints or clues as to what should be done.<n><n>`The task:` `Design an algorithm that searches for 'Jones' within a string.<n><n>Input:` `Given the the empty string, will it return a boolean output? (It wont be false) Will it return a single string that is 'Jones' as an empty set? Will the algorithm not contain something? The algorithm will return a boolean output and the input will be the empty string.`<n><n>### Wrong response 1:`The output won't contain 'Jones' it will be just empty sets.`<n><n>### Correction for the above example: The output will contain the empty sets, but then it wont contain 'Jones' as well. Instead, you must return an empty set with no elements, and that is what will be returned. The empty set can also contain the empty set and this is what will be returned when the empty string is inputted.`<n><n>### Input<n>`Write a statement that makes an informed comment about which choice(s) in the following sets are better than the others. Use the word, 'better' in your statement.<n><n>Option A. The one who is the fastest learner. Option b. The person who works hardest. Option c. The most diligent
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Having a car in the city seemed to be more trouble than it was worth, the man still had to walk to and from the what after commuting? Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question was whether it was more trouble than it was in the city. The man had to have a vehicle but it didn't say what type.<n><n>Choice A: The man didn't want to own a driveway hence it's not a correct answer.<n><n>Choice B: There's no contextual information about the event the man had to go to.<n><n>Choice C: The man still did not want to own a "scrap heap". So it's not a right choice either.<n><n>Choice D: The parking garage would be the option that makes the least sense as the city was giving the man lots of issues as it didn't feel like home to him.<n><n>Choice E: While the what is needed, the man did not wanted to own a repair shop in the city instead he had to walk around it<n><n>Answer: E: repair shop<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where would a ticket help you to get to a different country? Choices:  A: train station B: baseball stadium C: lottery D: movie E: bus<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Where would a ticket help you get to a different country. Choices:  A. train station B. baseball stadium C. lottery D. movie E. bus<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Choice A is incorrect because the statement of where a ticket would help a person to get to a different county does not relate to trains and stations, train stations may help you get around a city or town but they do not have anything special for ticketing purposes. Additionally, no country does not have a train station for ticketing purposes which again eliminates choice A.<n><n>Choice B is incorrect because a baseball stadium could be used to refer to the place that a baseball game is held at but in a country or town a baseball stadium is not used specifically for ticketing purposes it is a sports facility used to host sports events like baseball.<n><n>Choice C is incorrect because a ticket to win the lottery is to get the cash or prizes that the lottery offers.<n><n>Choice D is incorrect because the movie theater is not a place where you use a ticket to get in just the person who sells you the ticket. <n><n>Choice, E is incorrect because the word bus is missing in the choices hence it eliminates that option.<n><n>Therefore the correct answer is, choice B, "bus." <n><n># Challenge:<n><n>Input: What's the problem with this? Choices: <n><n>### Demontration:<n>This sentence begins with a question. Therefore, we interpret the entire statement as an action or command that the person is asking for. <n><n>In the sentence 'what's the problem with....'. What is the action or the command? To provide an answer we must ask more questions, is the problem? <n><n>If I respond with a simple answer, what is the solution, I may just make an unsupported assertion rather than providing a supporting answer. <n><n><n>### Input Choices: <n>Here is the rest of the question what's the problem with giving an answer along with showing your work, without any supporting details? Choices:  B: I know <n>C: It's not my job <n>D: I'm not allowed <n>E: I don't understand <n>F: I just didn't think about it<n><n>### Demotration:<n><n>Let's assume that "A, it

Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n><n>### Response:		The question doesn't indicate the type of shower, so any choice can be made.<n>### Demonstion:<n>If you want A, you need to clarify what kind of shower.<n>If you want B, the question needs to be completed: A shower is an expected facility when you reserve a _________, so any choice can apply.<n><n>Answer: C: motel room<n><n>### input:A wolfish person is often described as being full of _________ Choices A: what B: how C: who D: why E: when<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The choice of "who" or "that" would be appropriate.<n>The word "what" is often used as a synonym, often with other modifiers like "pretty" or "cute" in front of the "what" as in: the puppy is so cute, I wanna squeeze him, what do you think?<n><n>Answer:  C: who<n><n>### Input:"A good idea" is an understatement. An even better word for this expression is"___________" Choices A: not enough B: not nearly enough C: just right D: exactly right E: not at all<n><n>### Response:"A good idea" could be understated, and while you may be able to replace it with any of the words: not enough, not nearly enough, just right, even better, etc... you must replace it with the "better" word, meaning 2nd best/the best of two.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Not enough: Not enough for what? You want 4, that's pretty much more than enough, you want 5, that's still more than enough.<n>Not nearly enough: Not nearly enough for what? You know, it's not nearly enough to make you happy.<n>Just right: I like it just right, but I really want it exactly right.<n>Even better: You just said I might like it just right, so wouldn't it be better if you were sure it was even better?<n>Answer: E: not at all.

It doesn't say Lindy didn't want to. So, he wouldn't have lived anywhere if he didn't want.  Because he did not want to go where, then he would not be going somewhere, so then there is not somewhere for him to be going.<n><n>### Choice. A: republican party<n><n>### Rational:<n><n>### Choices. B,C,D, E.  are incorrect.<n><n>### If there is a choice with the words “not a...”  choose “not a...” not “...not...”<n><n>### Lindy didn’t want to live somewhere or going somewhere

"to be heard" is not what the question meant; it is about something that happens to people at a counseling session that is not mentioned in the question.<n><n>## The instructions can be written to test a specific skill. <n>## Instructions that ask the student to respond to something related to the work they presented.<n>## Instructions given can have multiple questions attached to a single task.<n>## Instrucions that are task based and are not open ended.<n>## Instuctions that are open ended.<n>## The instructions can include an instruction to include or explain something. <n>## The instructions can have multiple questions asked.<n>## Instrucion can ask for the student to provide a statement on a situation.<n>## Instrucitons can ask for the student explain something. <n><n>## Instruction: What did the writer say that wasn't true?<n><n>### Input (what the writer said): If you think you're the only one who has trouble in college, you should meet a few 5th graders.<n><n>### Rationales (What the writer means to say): The writer doesn't believe that college students are the only ones who struggle in college. They believe that 5th graders are the ones who are having trouble in college.<n><n>### Answer: The writer doesn't think that college students are the ONLY ones who struggle in college, she thinks that they are ALSO the ones having trouble in college. <n><n>### Input(the writer said): The writer said that college students are the ones who are struggling and the 5th graders<n><n><n><n>## Input asks for information such as specific details about a situation or experience. The response can be a detailed explanation of something described in the prompt, or an explanation of something in general that relates to it.<n>## Input can ask for information such as specific examples to support/exemplify an idea. <n><n>## Rationale:<n>The rationale asks for the student to write a response that gives specific examples to support their response. <n><n>## Input (what the teacher asks): For example, a student is given a book to read and asks if they are expected to summarize it on the test.<n><n>## Rationale (what the teacher means to ask):
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:What might someone do who is having fun? Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The task asks a person what they might do when they are having fun, leading the answer to be of an action. <n> <n><n>### Rationale:<n>Choice A, "being happy," implies a state of happiness that is separate from doing something. <n> <n>Choice B, "glee," is a word often associated with dancing but isn't limited to just that. This can be considered an action of some kind, but the word "glee" itself is too vague to be the ideal answer. <n> <n>The word choice is "may laugh", and laugh is a word typically associated with jokes or joy. Laughter is often associated with having fun, so this response is also acceptable. <n> <n>Thus, the statement that someone might laugh when they are having fun answers the task that is being posed.<n><n>### Input:"He has decided to _____ in the mountains" Choices:  A" take" B" walk" C" climb" D" climb" <n><n>### Response:"What will the person do?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>This statement is telling us that this person is currently in the middle of making his/her choice of what to do. It may be possible that there is some more information missing from the sentence and that the sentence may be unintentionally saying another statement that says he has chosen to climb "in the mountains." There is a lot of information missing in this question. In addition, there is no verb or subject mentioned in the question, which is important to establish in the sentence.<n><n>This choice is not necessary because the student is able to choose any activity in the sentence and answer the question.<n><n>## Exercise 1<n>Use all the information provided to complete one of the statements. Then, write a response that asks a followup question that appropriately completes another statement.<n><n>You can use whatever words you feel right from the sentence or the instructions. You can use it in a different order, you can delete any information, and you can add anything to the sentence!<n><n>You can see that the answer part is the follow up question part. As for the first set of question, the answer is under instructions.<n><n>### Task:A person might work hard for a long period of time to achieve a goal.<n>The person's goal is to help others live a better life.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The old barn was beyond salvation, they had to demolish it before they could what? Choices: A: make B: praise C: attract D: build E: mend<n><n>Choice A,'make,' means to create, but it needs to make something as part of the process. Therefore, it can't be applied to demolishing. This eliminates it from consideration. <n><n>Choice D, 'entice,' can mean to attract or to appeal to someone, but it is not directly related to demolishing the barn. <n><n>Choice C, 'raise,' can mean to create in elevation, but it cannot build an entirely new structure. It does not follow here. This leaves us with Choice B, 'destroy,' as the correct choice. <n><n>### Instructions:What did the scientist want to study about the plant? Choices: 1. Answers 2. Plants 3. Flowers 4. Seeds 5. Grass<n><n>### Demons:<n>Input: What did the scientist wanted to study about the plant. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B: eat<n><n>### Input:"A" could be written as:<n>```<n>"They wanted to eat dinner"<n>```<n>### Rationale:<n>In this response, you will be asked to identify which choice best fits an incomplete phrase. In these instances, it is important to read and comprehend the context as well as determine which choice best fits the sentence without necessarily guessing. <n>

However, the statement only mentions one particular place, the loft, which therefore indicates that the student searched for the holiday decoration in the loft.<n><n>Hence, the correct answer is C: [Loft](https://www.google.com/search?q=pic+of+loft&rlz=1C1CHBF_enUS898US898&tbm=isch&source=iu&ictx=1&fir=Dx6d2h41bDmZjM%252ClNZY9uEeWjzpAQM%252C_%253BJG9HXRG87wb-WM%252CXLj-4oMkLjL1kM%252CL5rZZJiRQ6RQM%253B_%253BAyf2YFNfKy14ZM%253BR409p_hXEv9Ky6cM%252CTp088uYVoL7gM%252CV5X2kVpFU4U5yM%252CNnKsxbWmGHmM%253BFbBKXw72_qZWM%252CG2kM0jXZ9FNQM%254DIQ%253D%253D&fir=Dx3b2gf_8xV4-LM%252CDn563Bg4uTJHgM%253BO%253BaUAaUuMsN3XJiM%252CFnPX3U_YpZ5bM%252CI41H-3Lv5M6JtM%253BEWf-r8JjXfU3x

This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:HOw do you carry potatos home? B: restaurants does not directly answer the quesiton. C: farmer's does not directly answer it as well. There was no time to list every place to purchase a grocery bag. E: bushel does not directly answer it either, its a type of container<n>Answer: B: grocery<n><n>### Input Question 1. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where do almost all people live? Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A: football stadium<n><n>### Rationale for answer: The statement claims that almost all people (the word "almost" means that the majority of people) live somewhere.<n><n>Choice A, "(the word) football stadium", is the only choice given that is a place where a large group of people might gather together which would indicate that this place is the most fitting answer.<n><n>Choice B, "(the word) apartment", is a more specific reference to individuals than "people," but since people live in apartments, it doesn't quite fit.<n><n>Choice D-E, "(the words) surface of the earth" and "(the words) car show" are general references to people more than specific places where most people live.<n><n>Therefore, the correct answer is A, "football stadium."<n>

Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		<n>Confirmation: The instructions said "instituting civil action," which is a term commonly understood to refer to actions related to the US judicial system. However, the answer could range from actions that take place in a judicial or administrative context or outside of it. For example, protests are also actions that can be initiated to advocate or oppose something, so it is also an appropriate choice if the answer is a different term for instituting.<n>Evaluation: The answer can be either an action or a term, but the correct answer should fit both categories. <n><n>Rationales: If you are looking for other terms to use to describe instituting a civil action, "protest" could be the best option. Protesters can be people who have a problem with how an action is being taken and choose as a means to convey their objection. Therefore, protests will have a strong impact and may affect a large group of people.<n>However, the word "riot" could be a good choice if it is talking about a large-scale unrest, even if the unrest could occur at the same time as other activities. For example, protestors may become impatient or angry and instigate a riot. In many cases, a riot occurs during other events, whether political, social or religious. <n><n>There are also cases where people may refer to some events as a riot without having a direct relationship to anything that could be categorized as a riot, such as when students behave badly and disobey people. In this case, the act of instituting civil action can be considered a form of riot.<n>Ultimately, both definitions fit, so the correct choice is "protest." Choice A: confusion can refer to multiple actions, and in this context, it would not be an appropriate answer as it does neither fit the context of taking action and nor the use of instituting in the instruction. Choice B: complications is unrelated to another term for institutition civil actions as it is simply a term used to describe confusion. The term "riot" (choice D) is unacceptable because although it has something to do with rioting, it doesn't include the word "civil". Finally, Choice E: protest E is not a good answer because it doesn't necessarily have to be civilly instituted to be a protest, which may refer to

Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>  - The response must be phrased in the affirmative because of the use of 'where".<n>  - If the response is 'new mexico', the only 'habitat' available will be desert animals or plants. This is the best choice because you don't state that the lizard is found ONLY in new mexico, as you should if you want to stay in context<n>  - However, if the response includes 'japan' 'utah' or other place names that imply the presence of animals native to the area, then the response is incorrect<n><n>Input: The only way to make sure your response follows your teacher’s instructions is to  A: read the instructions carefully B: repeat your sentence out loud to yourself C: ask questions D: listen to what your teacher says E: check with your teacher at each step<n>Rationales:<n>Choice A: "Carefully" does not indicate a specific step or the order of steps to follow. <n><n>Choice D: "Listen to what your teacher says" can be a potentially helpful step in the process of writing a response. However, it doesn't actually indicate a step to take, so this choice must be eliminated. This is akin to asking a yes or no question.<n><n>Choice B makes no sense. Why would the teacher respond to the student repeating their sentence out loud to themselves instead of when you asked a question?<n><n>Choice C is almost acceptable, except it is not limited to one step, as is suggested in the instructions. It seems to indicate that multiple steps can be taken to ensure the response is correct. <n><n>Choice C, if read more critically, does not make a clear statement that states the only way to make sure the response is correct is to ask the teacher at each step. Therefore, this correct choice is not a direct answer to the above question, implying the student should ask questions at multiple steps.   <n><n>Correct choice E indicates that the student checks with the teacher at each step to ensure the response conforms to the teacher's instructions. <n><n>Choices A, D, and B are not correct as they do not specify that the response must follow the teacher's instructions exactly.<n><n>Thus, the correct answer is C: check with your teacher<n><n>### Input : The word below has more letters than any other word in the Alphabet. Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Response: The options for keeping a curling iron vary based on the location, accessibility and needs. <n>C: use implies that curling iron is used by the people. It's an action that implies that people use this curling iron every day. This can be inferred from the question.  <n>A: bathroom means that most people use curling iron in the bathroom which means they do not use it daily and they also have other ways to curl their hair. <n>D: hair salon tells us that it is more likely that people store their curling iron in the hair salon instead of somewhere else because there is no need to unpack and pack it into a bag on a regular basis. <n>B: walkway, implies that people keep their curling in walkway. This choice is incorrect. The question is asking where they usually keep it, not where they keep it when it is being used. The options for location don't match the wording of the question. To summarise, the answer is A: bathroom. <n>E: drawer implies that people keep it in the drawer in the bathroom when they are using it. This option also not the most commonly used answer if they know to look in other location. The answer should be a more commonly used answer for a question like this where the location is important and the key information is missing. <n><n>### Further explanation:<n>The question is asking about where do most people keep curling iron stored which implies the location (where they keep it). It doesn't tell whether the users use it on a daily or weekly basis. A and D are not the best answer  as they do not really answer to the question. <n><n>The choices in A: bathroom is the best answer because it is the most often used and it contains the information that people keep in their daily life. <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:What does a master carpenter use to put holes in objects? Choices:  A : a laptop B : a laptop computer C : a laptop brand D : a laptop style E : a laptop version<n><n><n><n><n>### Review Questions:<n>In what ways can a teacher and parent collaborate to increase a child's ability to complete homework?<n>Answer: <n>A:  Allow the teacher and parent to understand each other's expectations of the child's work.<n><n>B:  Encourage communication and understanding between the teacher and the parent.<n><n>C:  Allow for different methods of completing tasks or problem-solving.<n><n>D: Discuss the teacher and parent's expectations of their child's work ethic and performance.<n><n><n>How can a student prepare to succeed in school?<n>Answer:<n><n>A:  Keep a record of their progress and achievements to motivate them.<n><n>B: Keeping organized and focused is key to success.<n><n>C: They should be able to recognize and identify the various forms of assessment that are required in school and understand how their own personality affects their learning process.<n><n>D: Students should make an effort to seek out and complete additional assignments that assist with their academic development.<n><n><n>What is the purpose of "writing for reading"?<n>Answer: Writing effectively and concisely, regardless of how you may perceive your writing style, will enhance both the quality (readability etc) and accessibility of the final piece.

There is no contradiction when these two are true.<n><n>Choice C, "glee," is the only word which is mentioned in the statement. By recognizing that glee is the word being referred to in the statement, the student will provide a correct response. <n><n>Choice D, opera is not included in the statement and is also not a proper response since the statement does not mention it specifically.<n><n>Choice E, injuries, is not a word which is mentioned in statement. <n>Therefore, answer is B: "being happy"<n><n>### Input:"You can’t see into someone’s head."<n><n>### Justify why these answers are true.<n><n>1. Choices:  Choices:  A new apartment B a new school C a new job D a new classroom E a new home<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: "accommodated": To make something more suitable to, or appropriate for, a particular person or thing: they are providing a comfortable living space that is accommodated to your needs." ANSWER:D, A new school is more suitable to someone than a new home and is more comfortable than a job. <n><n>### Sample:<n>* I was having trouble understanding their [a]accommodated [B]apartment.[C]school.[D]classroom. [E]home<n><n>### Output: The output must be written in paragraph form, as shown in the responses above. <n>### Submission format:<n>For in-class participation, write your code on the interactive whiteboard or sheet of paper provided. <n>For submission, the answer must be submitted in an email to your teacher, so the answers are viewable in Google Sheets for grading.

Choices:  A: shelf B: desktop C: cabinet D: kitchen E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer here is "C" because the cupboard is an area specifically designated for storing things like coffee mugs and dishes after they are dry or cleaned. <n><n>Choice "A" is incorrect because the shelf is not an area that is generally designated or used for such purposes but for things like books and other items that might be placed on top of it. <n><n>Choice, "B", is incorrect because the desktop is not designated, especially not for purposes specifically related to dishes after they are cleaned or dried. <n><n>Choice D, the kitchen, is also incorrect because it's not where one puts their coffee mug(s) after it is dry. The choice "E", the cupboard or cupboard area in the kitchen, could be appropriate and correct. The correct place where the student would put their coffee mug after it is dry is the kitchen cupboard (a cupboard, cabinet, or cupboard in a kitchen), which is where items are stored when not being used, including coffee mugs on a shelf or dried in the kitchen area. Choices:  A: think B: patent C: determined D: work hard E: relax<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: This question is asking the student to identify the result of the sentence, which in this case is the action that is completed or the condition that occurs. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where can you store a small notepad on your person? Choices:  A: back pocket B: meeting C: drug store D: home E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C: "meeting." The meeting could be a gathering of students, a team project, a class, a presentation etc.<n><n>### Input:"I wonder how you could tell the difference between a regular calculator and a TI-83 Plus (Titanium) Graphing Calculator.?" Choices:  A& B: graphing capabilities B: larger screen C: higher storage B: cheaper price <n><n>### Response:"You might notice a size difference, and the TI-83 uses a battery while the TI-84 doesn’t. Another difference is that the TI-89 has a larger storage and a 300 x 600 liquid crystal display. The TI-89 also performs complex functions like integration and matrix calculations." Answer from - [196]<n>[ https://www.calculatorsoup.com/?q=difference+between+ti-83+plus+ti-84+ti-89](https://www.calculatorsoulp.com/?q=158498]<n><n><n>### Input:[http://www.pbslearningmedia.org/resource/msdv4.sci.life.practices.eating/how-long-is-too-long-to-eating/]

Choice E, "learning about world," is a redundancy of what "gives" means, so it can be discarded. Choice C, "worry," is not related to reading a paper or getting information from the news, so it can also be tossed. Choices A, "get angry" and B "concern," is similar and in most cases are too general for a news article. <n><n>There is only a choice with "education" and "learning about world" both in it which are the only choices related to getting knowledge through learning.<n>Answer: C and E, education and "learning about world."<n><n>### Input :<n><n>### Democracy is a good form of government.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Instructions: In this response, complete the response by choosing, and correctly writing (1) what you believe makes the given text unimportant, and then (2) why it is not important. Do not write a paragraph; just provide one, single sentence. Do not make the task any longer, because this will lower your score on each part of the task. As stated in the question, it would probably take someone twelve years to go to school. Furthermore, with all the work you put in to obtain your degree, you might feel bored, inspired, or bored and inspired, but this isn't what is directly intended. This is what is implied in the question.<n><n><n><n>### Input :An old lady comes out of the local post office with her mail to discover that her house has burned to the ground. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		Answers:A is clearly incorrect. It doesn't mention anything about the village being in an area that has the word "rural" in it.<n>B: also seems like a stretch. It doesn't explicitly answer the question of villages either.<n>C: makes the statement "This will be the subject of our next work on urban areas." Not sure exactly what that means but it kind of sounds like they mean that the next question will be about urban areas. <n>D: seems to be the correct answer. <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that most appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## Example Response:<n>Choice A is obviously incorrect.<n>Choice B: also seems like a reach. It doesn't clearly answer the question of villages.<n>Choice C: is not really an answer at all. It just says that the next paragraph or section will be about cities. Not really that illuminating.<n>Choice D: seems to be the most direct, concise, correct answer.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>A: clearly incorrect.<n>B: seems like a stretch.<n>C: is not an answer because it just says the next paragraph would be about cities.<n>D: is the most logical, concise, and correct answer.<n>Answer: D: seems like a logical answer<n><n>### Next:<n>A response that appropriately answer the task.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D: is the response which most adequately answers the task.<n><n>---<n>### Extension Questions<n><n>* Is there a time when the teacher asks too many questions?<n>* How do students feel about being asked so many questions by their teachers?<n><n>### Answers<n><n><n>Yes, there is a time when a teacher asks too many questions. Some students feel uncomfortable and intimidated with a teacher who constantly asks questions and expects immediate answers.<n><n>---<n><n>### Further explanation/clarification<n><n>- This task includes an image. Students should be able to understand the questions and answer them based on the information conveyed through the image. The student's response should not only be accurate and correct but also organized and coherent, with attention to the task guidelines. <n><n>## Expected Response/Structure<n><n>- Each response will cover all the given guidelines. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Shane was supposed to speak at his fathers funeral.  He was a clown, and acted very ridiculous.  This cheerfulness turned off people who expected the funeral to be what? Choices:  A: solemn B: compete C: serious D: somber E: straightforward<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A, "solemn", means solemnity in a strict sense and might indicate that the funeral should be taken seriously, but this would go against what the passage seems to state - that Shane was expected to act flippantly. <n><n>Choice D, “somber”, could be another incorrect word in this sentence - to mean to be somber it would say about one’s condition, but in this sentence it does not describe the condition of Shane or the people who attended the funeral, but it does describe the funeral itself, and it should be described as "solemn" when it talks about the people who attended, not the funeral itself. That makes Choice B a possible answer.<n><n>Choice E, “straightforward,” is similar to Choice D in that it discusses the person’s state or condition, not the funeral as a whole.<n><n>Rationales:<n>Choice B, “sincere,” was not eliminated because there is a double meaning for sincere. It can mean honest (like a person is honest). It can also be used to say someone is sincere, meaning they’re sincere about being honest.  In this scenario, Shane’s behavior was not sincere. He was ridiculous, so it was not sincere behavior, and it's not used to mean about a funeral being honest, because that would go against what we all know about funerals.  Therefore, the double meaning is not useful in this scenario. <n><n>Choice C, “serious,” has the opposite meaning to what was stated in the sentence because it's being said that Shane should have been a clown and not take things seriously. If the funeral was serious, then perhaps a wake would be better. <n><n>Choice F, "straightforward," was eliminated because it described the person, not the funeral. <n><n>There is no other Choice that fits. Therefore, it must have been choice B, “competitive.”<n><n>Answer: B: Competitive<n><n>

Choices:  a: 368 million  b: 36 million  c: 101 million  d: 590 million  e: 20 million <n>Rationales:The options in order to be less than the answer would have to be less than half, or one-thousands. 368 being about 10 to the 6th power is not less than, so this choice can be eliminated.<n>Options A, 101 million, and E, 20 million. being greater than 420 million are not options, so they can be eliminated as well.<n><n>Option C, 36 million is about 10 to 4th power, which is slightly less than 425 million.<n><n><n>Option B 36 million is significantly less than 420, so this choice is the most fitting.<n><n>### Response1: B: 36 million<n><n>### Input2: In 2015, more than 15 terabytes  of data  was sent over  the internet per second. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where did the person have to walk downstairs to get the tool? Choices:  A: hardware store B: basement C: garage D: repair shop E: the library.<n><n>### Response:		<n>We have to walk all the way up to the top of the stairs to get the tool at the hardware store. If the question said, "We have to walk to the hardware _______________ ", the answer would be at the hardware shop." So if you go up one level, you go all the way down!<n>Answer: The library.<n>Rationales: Answers were marked for completeness and concisely. The instructions stated that only one word was needed to answer in a concise manner. The instruction provided a word choice and only one word choice was needed. The following choices were chosen to meet the requirements of the instruction. Choice A: 5th floor: to be clear that the top floor was 5th floor and the basement is 1st floor the word "way" is used only one time. Choice B: to say "hardware store" is redundant and chooses one word and the one word is the proper answer. Choice C; the answer is the "1" floor, or in the basement.  Again, one word is required. Choice D: if the question said, "we have to walk to the repair shop, the answer would be at repair shop. So if you go up, one level, you go down. Choice E was not selected because it is the last possible answer in the choices. Choice E: the last choice in the instruction is the library.<n><n>####<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where do people traditionally get information about the world? Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer would be Choice "A", which is "book". The question is asking for "where do people traditionally get the information about the world" and books would fall under "information about the world". Even though people get information from all sources like "meetings", "television", and "newspapers", these sources still require some type of book to be able to be viewed. Some other sources people get information from that the question says are "book", are "the internet" and "radio".<n><br><n><br><n>### Input:You have a list with two elements and want to select another element. Choices:  A:"the second element" B:"another element" C:"the first element or the second element" D:"one of the two elements" E:"the first or last element"<n><n>### Response<n>The response would be Choice "C", which is "the first element or the last element". When selecting an element, the first element on a list cannot be selected as it has already been selected and this element can be considered the "first element". The last element on the list cannot be selected as the question only asks for another element and this element is already the last. <n><br><n><n>### Output:Your answer choice for "The first element or the second elements"" is correct!!!<n><n>### Output Text:<n>Output: Your answer choice for "The second element or the first element"" is correct!!!
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Lizards need the sun to heat themselves in order to regulate their body temperatures, hence why you will see them still on rocks. Choice A is wrong since rocks can't absorb heat, this would mean that they would be completely immobile until their body temperature would reach equilibrium with the current surrounding temperatures.<n><n>### Input:"Mammals have a circulatory system to keep their internal body temperature constant. How do birds keep their body steady in order to survive?" Choice: A: Birds sweat and fly slower than mammals B: Birds peck their way down to the ground before falling to the ground C: Birds stay in places with heat and sun D: Birds are warm-blooded and they shed their feathers E: Birds take flight above the ground and go back to the ground F: Birds peck to dig their food and they are warm-blooded<n><n>### Input The sun is what causes us to perceive heat? Choice: A: Sun rays B: Sun heat rays C: Sun light rays<n><n>### Input<n>Lizards need the Sun as their way to receive heat, as well as to be able to regulate their body heat and keep their body temperature at an optimal level. Therefore, Lizards require a place to stay and take the sun's heat in order to warm themselves to be able to regain heat whenever possible. <n><n>### Input How do lizards survive? Choice: A. By taking care of themselves<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>What would the ground be for shadows? <n>The ground is typically used as a reference point for shadow sizes, and sometimes shadows cast on the ground are considered interesting and meaningful. For example, if the shadow cast on the ground appears very long, it might indicate that a person is undergoing significant personal growth. <n><n>While the ground does not always appear in shadows, it can be a useful place to look for them. If a person is expecting to see a shadow on a particular object, they may look for it in unexpected places. For example, if they are expecting to see the shadow of a clock on the ceiling, they may search for it in the window as well.<n><n>Answer: D: ground<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Situation:** <n>Someone is missing from your classroom. Your first instinct is to:_________. <n><n>### Rationales:<n>The options include: <n>"Pray" - praying on the student not to be sick.<n>"Leave a note on the desk," in the classroom.<n>"Notify your supervisor."<n>"Wait for the student to return."<n>"Notify the police."<n><n>Choice A, leaving a note on the student's desk, might be a good idea, depending on the situation.<n><n>Choice B, 'notifying your supervisor', is a clear example of reporting a behavioral/situational issue, which doesn't fit properly.<n><n>Choice D might also be a very valuable option, as a missing student may not simply be a concern for a teacher but also the student's family.<n><n>Choice C, "waiting for the student to return", is too vague and doesn't provide much detail on what this specific teacher would be doing. <n><n>Choice D, notifying the police, is a clear and definitive action, but it may not be necessary. <n><n>There is a very strong possibility that the student in question is doing a research paper elsewhere, away from school or at another school location. It also seems likely that they have an explanation of their absence.<n><n>Answer: ​​<n>"notify the police"<n><n>Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>If an employee has been absent more than 4 days in a row,  your first step should be to: <n>Choose one:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Rationales: The statement says that the teacher wanted more than just the answer and work shown. This implies she wanted additional elements that would support or illustrate the answer. <n><n>Choice A, "prepare dinner," is unrelated to an academic or learning context, so it can be eliminated. <n><n>Choice B, "evaluate progress," could be a possible answer in some scenarios, but it doesn't fit well within the context of giving an answer. It is more related to monitoring the student's overall growth or development in the subject not in a particular answer.<n><n>Choice D, "work in school," is a general expectation, not specific to presenting or enhancing an answer. <n><n>Choice E, "prove their point," could potentially fit, but it's similar to simply "showing your work" which has already been mentioned, so this choice is repetitive and doesn't add anything new. <n><n>Therefore, Choice C, "include examples", is the most fitting answer as examples can be a crucial part of structuring and enhancing the clarity of an answer.<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:George ruined the surprise.  How did he do so? Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.  Demonstration: The statement says that George ruined the surprise. The statement doesn't specify that the ruined surprise was planned, so this rule is applicable. Choice A, "hiding", is not related to academic or learning context, but rather related to general actions. Choice B, "accidentally ruining the surprise", could be a possible answer, but it doesn's fit because it could also fit in Choice A. Choice D, "knowingly ruining the surprise", is repetitive, so it can be easily eliminated. Choice E, "planning", doesn't fit well with the context of the statement. Choice C, "expectation ruining the surprise", fits best because it is similar to the example that is described within the context of the statement so is the most fitting choice among the rest.<n><n>Choice C:  A: hiding<n><n>### Input<n><n>The answer to this question was given and now everyone needs help with it.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer the same multiple-choice question. Demonstration: Everyone has the same issue/problem, and they all have the same question of "what's the answer?", to which we are asked to answer the same. Choice A, hiding, does not fit in this scenario. Choice B, accidentally ruins the surprise, is related to the same scenario because everyone is asked/asking the same question. Choice C, expectation ruining the surprise, as stated in the scenario, is a very common answer to our question. Choice D, knowingly ruining the surprise, does not fit well because the statement does not say or imply that the answer is purposely hidden from someone. Choice E, planning, fits the scenario because everyone got asked the same, to which we are asked the same.<n><n>Choice C :  A : hiding <n><n>### Input : The teacher wanted more than just a number answer. She was looking at examples, steps and all the work.<n><n>### Input Response  : Answer the following multiple-choice questions. Demonstration : The teachers wanted to see all the steps, and she was looking for all the work. Choice A was looking for the food, and that didn't meet the criteria. Choice B was food, but the food is not the work. Choice C it was all
